title: Challenger banks Handelsbanken and Secure Trust report surge in profits as consumer confidence grows
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 21, 2015, 13:25 BST - UK Markets close in 3 hrs 5 mins Challenger banks Handelsbanken and Secure Trust report surge in profits as consumer confidence grows By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 47 minutes ago +100.00 
Banking bosses say the Conservative victory has helped to drive business in the growing sector 
Customers are becoming increasingly confident in the wake of the general election, driving more business to the UK's growing challenger banking sector, the boss of Arbuthnot Banking Group has said. 
Sir Henry Angest, chairman and chief executive of Arbuthnot Banking Group, which owns challenger bank Secure Trust, said the Conservative victory in May’s general election has banished political uncertainty in the market, helping to drive profit growth. 
New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) loan volumes at Secure Trust Bank more than doubled to £426m in the six months to June 30, while customer lending jumped 90pc to £852.3m and customer deposits grew by 75pc to £835.1m. 
That drove pre-tax profits 40pc higher to £16m and prompted management to boost the interim dividend payout by 6pc. 
The profit figures were flattered by an acquisition. But strip that out, along with other one-off costs, and underlying profits still increased by 14pc. 
Secure Trust, a listed subsidiary of Arbuthnot Banking Group, typically offers customers unsecured personal loans, but it has also started to expand into small business lending . 
A branch of Handelsbanken in Malmö, Sweden 
Meanwhile, Handelsbanken, the Swedish challenger bank with a growing British presence , also reported a jump in earnings, with operating profits up 47pc in the first-half, boosted by higher business and mortgage lending and a big rise in deposits. 
Operating profits at the lender's UK arm - which has almost 200 branches - rose 47pc to £180.5m, while loan losses on the portfolio remained at just 0.02pc. 
Challengers like Secure Trust and Swedish lender Handelsbanken are seeking to take market share from the high-street banks, exploiting both the unpopularity of the big banks in the wake of the financial crisis and changes in the rules that make it easier for both new banks to establish themselves and for customers to move between banks . 
However, things might be getting more difficult for them following changes to corporation tax announced in the Summer Budget. 
Paul Lynam, who heads up Secure Trust, has previously complained that small banks will be hit hard by the 8pc additional corporation tax announced in the emergency Budget in July. 
He told the Telegraph that he and the rest of the sector feels "intense frustration" at the new tax .
